abstracts.cdata!:
The audit rates the Suralaya Thermal
            Power (STP) Project outcome as moderately satisfactory, with
            unlikely sustainability, and modest institutional
            development impacts, in contrast to the Implementation
            Completion Report (ICR) ratings of unsatisfactory outcomes,
            and substantial institutional development impacts.
            Conversely, it concurs with the ICR ratings of the Sumatera
            and Kalimantan Power (SKP) Project of unsatisfactory
            outcome, and unlikely sustainability, but upgrades
            institutional development impacts from modest to
            substantial. The findings of the Thematic Overview suggest
            that the radically changed circumstances in the Indonesian
            power sector, are conducive to the Bank's continuing
            reluctance to support new generation projects, which may
            have to be reconsidered, and alternative ways of structuring
            mixed public-private generation projects need to be
            explored. Lessons drawn from the performance assessment of
            these two projects include: 1) meticulous coal quality
            monitoring is essential for a plant where minor differences
            in coal characteristics can have a significant impact on
            boiler efficiency, with substantial financial consequences;
            2) a secure long-term supply contract for coal with the
            optimal characteristics for the Suralaya boilers may justify
            the payment of a price premium, because of the financial
            consequences of a poorer heat rate, plant unavailability due
            to more frequent outages, and increased maintenance costs;
            3) an automatic tariff adjustment mechanism can only operate
            satisfactorily under relatively stable macroeconomic
            conditions: variations in the exchange rate, fuel prices,
            and inflation, cannot be dealt with, through a technical
            formula that is de-linked from socio-political
            considerations; and, 4) project objectives should be
            directly linked to project components. Furthermore, compared
            to Specific Investment Loans, an Adaptable Program Loan
            would appear to be a more appropriate lending instrument for
            the pursuit of sector reforms that require consensus
            building, and are particularly suitable instruments in
            countries where the Bank has a regular sequence of lending
            operations in the same sector.
